lines.text:
[about working in the saw mill]
It didn't seem to worry most of the boys. They put in their time, looking ahead to payday. But not me. That paycheck wasn't money, it was a bill of sale. Three months of that, back to whiskey. It's been hard on your ma, but damn foolishness to one person is breath of life to another.
How do you see your chances, Kyle?

You don't think I got the gall to answer a question like that, do ya, in front of famous drivers like Tex Zimmerman, Rick Penny, Davie Baer? So why don't we wait 'til this race is over and the best man's won and I'm standing there kissing the trophy girl? Then you ask me that.
Junior, you got the talent and I got the bankroll. Now how many loads of white lighting you think it's gonna take to get you back running?
How much it gonna take you? I just gotta replace my car. You gotta find a new shoe who ain't got chickenshit in his veins.
Woo, you a hard case, kid.
Colt, I'm gonna whip your ass, along with everybody else. My car don't hold out, I'm gonna footrace with you!
What about arm wrestling?
Whatever it by-god takes.
What if you wreck your next one?
Well I go to work right here.

Down at the lumber mill, they tell the story about the near-sighted fellow who liked playing around with a buzz saw. Lost one finger. Two. Three. He kept right on playing 'till all five was gone. He looked at his hand and said "I'm beginning to think this here is a losing game."
That fella sounds like a fool to me.
Uh-huh. Now it just might be you didn't get my point. If you lose a race, you get other chances. If you lose runnin' liquor you get a prison cell, 'cause boy, they got your number.
So what? A little jail never hurt nobody.

If you got five seconds to spare, you tell me all you know about jail. Why, you don't know nothing. Not the first goddamn thing! And you're never gonna! Now, this is the only life I know, and I'm not gonna stop now, but my boys are gonna have somethin' different!
I don't know nothin' else.
And you never will, unless you stop right here!
How you've changed. Last time I saw you, you were gonna whip my ass with whatever it by-god takes. Now you want a job.
how long's it been since you won that thing, and do you want more?
Your manners haven't changed.
I don't want no job, neither. I work for nothin', take fifty percent of the prize money.
To begin with, I hire drivers on *my* terms.
And end up nowhere.
Where do you get off being so goddamn snotty?
I know my potential. So do you.
One race, twenty percent, you'll say forty, I'll say thirty. Yes or no?
You know, in today's world, you gotta obey rules and regulations. Now as far as the terms of your employment...

[grabs his first-place trophy from Colt]
I reckon this gives me a pretty fat hand, Colt, against you or anybody else I wanna race for.
You don't have a hand. You have a bad history, boy. If you're my driver, I sign the checks, I run the show, you drive. That's how the big boys play this game. Now are you in or out?
my crew, sixty percent of the prize money. Now you'll say forty, I'll say fifty. Yes or no?

[after an argument with Colt]
Six test runs in one afternoon, chewin' on my ass every minute of the way.
That's a real nut crusher.
Hey, man, let me lay something on you. Wait'll you drive for somebody who ain't won a race in ten months.
I don't see a gun at your head.
Oh yeah? What's that supposed to mean?
You don't feel like takin' orders, drive for yourself.
Boy, I never saw it fail. Nobody knows more than a rookie.
You make a move on me, I'll rip his lip off and give it to you for a key ring.
